questions.question:
Which symbol is used to start a single-line comment in Ruby?

```ruby
# This is a comment
puts "Hello"
```
questions.explanation: In Ruby, the # character starts a single-line comment. // and /* */ are used in JavaScript/C/Java; -- is typically used in SQL.

questions.question:
What will be the output of the following code?

```ruby
puts "Hello" # puts "World"
```
questions.explanation: Everything after # on the same line is a comment and is ignored. Only puts "Hello" is executed, so the output is Hello.

questions.question: Which of the following are valid ways to write comments in Ruby?
questions.explanation: Ruby supports single-line comments with # and multi-line comments with =begin ... =end. // and /* */ are not valid Ruby comment syntax.

questions.question:
What is the correct syntax for a multi-line comment in Ruby?

```ruby
=begin
This is a comment
=end
```
questions.explanation: Multi-line comments in Ruby use =begin at the start and =end at the end. /* */ is used in C/Java; <!-- --> is HTML.

questions.question:
What happens if `=begin` is indented with spaces?

```ruby
  =begin
  comment
  =end
```
questions.explanation: =begin and =end must start at column 1 (no leading whitespace or indentation). If indented, Ruby raises a syntax error.

questions.question:
What is the output of the following code?

```ruby
# puts "Hello"
puts "World"
```
questions.explanation: The first line is a comment, so puts "Hello" is not executed. Only puts "World" runs, producing the output World.

questions.question: Which statements about Ruby comments are correct?

options.A: Comments are ignored by the Ruby interpreter
options.B: Comments can appear after code on the same line

questions.explanation: Comments are ignored by the interpreter (A), can appear after code on the same line (B), and multi-line comments use =begin/=end (D). Comments do not affect execution (C is false).

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts 1 + 1 # + 5
```
questions.explanation: The part # + 5 is a comment, so only 1 + 1 is evaluated, resulting in 2.

questions.question:
Which line is treated as a comment?

```ruby
=begin comment
=end
```

options.C: Both lines and text between them

questions.explanation: Everything from the =begin line to the =end line (including both lines and the text between them) is treated as a comment.

questions.question:
Select all true statements about Ruby comment behavior with code below:

```ruby
puts "A" # comment
# puts "B"
```
questions.explanation: The first line executes puts "A", so A is printed (A is correct). The second line is a comment and is ignored (C is correct). B is not printed; comments do not change the program result (B and D are false).

questions.question:
What happens if `=end` is missing?

```ruby
=begin
comment
```
questions.explanation: A block comment must have both =begin and =end. Missing =end means Ruby cannot find where the comment ends and raises a syntax error.

questions.question: Which comment style is most commonly used in Ruby production code?
questions.explanation: Single-line comments with # are the most common in Ruby code. The =begin/=end block is used less often and can cause errors if indented.

questions.question:
What is the output of the following Ruby code?

```ruby
puts "Ruby" # comment here
# puts "Rails"
```
questions.explanation: Only puts "Ruby" is executed. The part after # on line 1 and the entire second line are comments, so Rails is not printed.

questions.question:
Which of the following lines will cause a syntax error?

```ruby
=begin
comment
  =end
```

options.A: =begin must start at the beginning of the line

questions.explanation: =end must start at column 1. When =end is indented (has leading whitespace), Ruby reports a syntax error.

questions.question: Which of the following are true about Ruby comments?

options.A: Anything after # on the same line is ignored
options.B: Comments can be placed after code

questions.explanation: Anything after # on the same line is ignored (A). Comments can be placed after code (B) and improve readability (D). Comments are not executed at runtime (C is false).

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts "A" # first
puts "B" # second
```
questions.explanation: The two puts calls print "A" and "B" respectively; each puts adds a newline, so the output is A, newline, then B (A\nB).

questions.question: Which statement about =begin and =end is correct?

options.A: They can appear anywhere in the line
options.B: They must start at column 1 (no indentation)

questions.explanation: =begin and =end must be at the beginning of the line (column 1), with no indentation. They can be used anywhere in the file, not only inside methods.

questions.question:
Given the code below, which lines are ignored by Ruby?

```ruby
puts 10
# puts 20
=begin
puts 30
=end
puts 40
```
questions.explanation: The line # puts 20 is a single-line comment; the =begin to =end block is a comment containing puts 30. Both are ignored. puts 10 and puts 40 are executed.

questions.question:
What is the output?

```ruby
puts "Hello" # comment
=begin
puts "World"
=end
```
questions.explanation: Only puts "Hello" runs. The part after # and the entire =begin ... =end block are comments, so puts "World" is not executed.

questions.question: Which symbol comments out the rest of the line in Ruby?
questions.explanation: In Ruby, # comments out from that position to the end of the line. // and /* belong to other languages; -- is commonly used in SQL.

questions.question:
What happens in the following code?

```ruby
puts "X" #
```
questions.explanation: puts "X" is executed; the part from # to end of line (including the # character) is a comment. The result is that X is printed.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a valid Ruby comment style?
questions.explanation: Ruby uses # for single-line comments and =begin/=end for multi-line. // is syntax from C/Java/JavaScript, not Ruby.

questions.question: Select all correct statements about comment placement in Ruby.

options.A: Comments can be on their own line
options.D: Comments can appear inside class definitions

questions.explanation: Comments can be on their own line (A), after statements on the same line (B), and inside class definitions (D). Comments do not have to be inside methods (C is false).
